comments:
Whenever I try to open Help via Help > Help Contents, I get a Browser 
showing "HTTP 404 - File not Found".

The problem goes away when I remove my user-level environment variable TMP 
which is pointing to I:\tmp. When I remove this user-level environment 
variable, the system-level variable becomes active, which is set to 
C:\Windows\Temp.
Yet on a colleague's machine, modifying environment variables does not help 
and he never gets the Eclipse Help system to work.

I'm pretty sure that the problem did not exist with Eclipse 3.0, and appeared 
the first time when I installed 3.0.1. BTW, I'm using JRE 1.4.2_07.

My personal feeling is that the problem might be due to tomcat policies 
forbidding access to some classfiles which are cached by the JVM in a JARfile 
cache in the TMP directory. This suspicion is because when I navigate to the 
Help Root at 127.0.0.1:57486, I see "Internal Application Server", so the help 
server seems to be running. And, the logfile at 
Workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.tomcat\catalina.2005-03-08.log 
contains the following:

WebappLoader[]: Deploying class repositories to work directory 
E:\PDE\eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.tomcat\ROOT
ContextConfig[]: Added certificates -> request attribute Valve
StandardManager[]: Seeding random number generator class 
java.security.SecureRandom

Created an attachment (id=18530)
Catalina.log logfile with exceptions

Can you delete the eclipse\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.tomcat 
directory and see if it helps.  After you delete, do not use the workspace 
with an older Eclipse.
Thanks.

I reproduced the problem with a plain fresh installation of Eclipse 3.0.1 and 
a new workspace. 
I can also reproduce it with Eclipse 3.1M5a.

As soon as I set environment variable TMP=I:\tmp the help system fails to 
work. When I set TMP=C:\tmp it works, even if I re-use the workspace that had 
failed in the previous invocation.

Thank you.
It looks like the user account used to run Eclipse does not have permission to 
read and write to I:\tmp directory.  VM uses the "java.io.tmpdir" for caching 
Jars accessed using jar: prtocol, and it has trouble doing so 
Is the directory on a shared drive, or are you running Eclipse as 
underprivileged user, while the directory I:\tmp is accessible by different 
user or Administrator?
You indicated "Windows All" for OS, are you running XP or 2000?

I'm running on Windows XP Professional SP1 (plus all MS-recommended hotfixes 
except SP2). My User-id has administrative privileges. From Windows Explorer, 
there is no problem whatsoever accessing I:\tmp. I:\tmp resides on a local 
disk. There is enough space on that disk.

I tried upgrading to JDK1.5_01 --> No difference.
I tried other directories for TMP:
  E:\tmp --> works.
  I:\tump --> fails when directory tump does not exist but works when tump 
exists.

Further investigations on my colleague's and my computer showed the following:
Both of us are using McAfee VirusScan Enterprise 8.0.0. 
When we _exclude_ the I:\tmp directory from the virus scanner, the Help System 
fails to work. When we _allow_ the virus scanner to run, the Help System 
works. Really weird isn't it!

My colleague had excluded the entire C:\ drive and all subdirectories: Help 
System failed. Removed the exclusion --> The Help System worked.

We tried to stop the entire McAfee VirusScan service: used the Windows Service 
Manager as well as Process Explorer to kill all services associated with Virus 
Scanning: the Help System failed to come up.

Could it be that there is some race condition, where a file is written into 
TMP and read before it is fully there - such that only when a Virus Scanner 
slows down the operation it works correctly? - It looks like the next step to 
go might be to try it on a freshly installed Windows XP system without any 
Virus Scanner. Unfortunately we don't have the time to try this, but perhaps 
Eclipse.org has some test machines which are freshly installed?

Whatever the directory that TMP points to should exist.
The caching of Jar is done by JRE, not help code, so I doubt a bug or race 
condition in caching is the problem.  The issue is likely caused by McAfee.  
There were these two reports bug 84508 and bug 85205 of some weird behavior.
Please also see bug 75462 that has a patch from Mcafee for another problem.
Help works for everybody else, so there is really nothing we can do or try to 
debug at eclipse.org.  I will mark this bug as WORKSFORME.  If you get more 
information please add to the bug.  If you find help code to be to blame, or 
have suggestion for a workaround help could put for others problems, please 
reopen this report.
Thank you.

An interesting post by Mike Melvin, today on eclipse-platform news group:

We have just been "upgraded", to McAfee VirusScan Enterprise 8.0 (from 
7.x), and my Eclipse Help system no longer works.  We have tried every 
setting possible in McAfee, and apart from uninstalling it or reverting 
back to v7.x, it simply will not work.  McAfee 8.0 has some new 
firewalling "features" that seem to be blocking Eclipse from starting 
the Help server, or connecting to it (I'm not sure which - but I am 
leanign towards the former).  There are no error messages in the log, it 
just says that the page is not found.  I have tried running the server 
on port 80 and turned off every single firewall setting I can find in 
McAfee to no avail.  Uninstalling/killing VirusScan solves the problem.

Has anyone seen this before or can suggest anything else?

Thanks,
Mark.

Well, this might be more widespread, or at least more critical than expected.  I
am having problems with both McAfee and Norton now.  I think it has something to
do with the firewall software detecting access to zipfiles (and potential
execution of Java/scripts?) in these temp folders, so it just blocks it thinking
it is malicious.  As a result, the server never starts up.

I have no idea how to fix this yet - we are still trying to find a workaround. 
This is fairly major for us as everyone here has a firewall "pushed" to our
workstations and we cannot disable it.  As a result, none of our Eclipse Help
works anymore.

Is it possible to re-open this bug??

I am reopenning the bug as per your request.  Martin, the reported should be 
able to do so as well.
I am using Zone Labs Integrity Client and Symanted Antivirus and don't see any 
effect of them on help.  Please keep us informed of your findings.

OK, some more information.  We seem to have solved our issue with McAfee, and
since I cannot confirm the issue with Norton yet, I can only assume it isn't
related to this particular bug (it could be as simple a stupid user...).

The latest McAfee patch (patch level 10 to VirusScan Enterprise 8.0i) seems to
have cured the problem we were seeing.  Looking through the resolved issues, the
only thing I can possibly connect to this failure is the following:

14. ISSUE
An "Access Denied" error appeared in an application that used the
"delete-on-close" flag when working with temporary files.  The file system
filter driver would lose track of the "delete-on-close" flag.

RESOLUTION:
The updated file system filter driver resolves this issue, allowing temporary
files to be utilized as expected.

As an interesting side note, we also found through testing that the Help system
would work fine if the On-Access Scan was enabled, and would fail when it was
disabled (the opposite of what you would expect).  I can only assume the above
issue (resolved by patch 10) had something to do with this.

I think it would be safe to close this bug again if Martin could perhaps
validate that patch 10 fixes his problem as well.  Thanks for re-opening.

More fun with McAfee...

Patch level 10 has indeed fixed our Eclipse Help issue, but seems to have
induced a new bug to do with accessing network shares (perhaps just samba-based,
I don't know).  This is starting to get off-topic from Eclipse-related behaviour
now, but I will log it here in case someone else runs into this issue.

We were getting Access Denied errors sporadically from our mapped network
drives, and I actually had a couple of corrupted check-ins to CVS as a result of
this that screwed up our Eclipse-based product build.  There seems to be a buggy
.dll in McAfee VirusScan Enterprise 8.0i patch level 10.  I was told to
unregister the scriptproxy.dll until a fix was found, and my problems should go
away.  We'll see.  So, for a workaround - if you have the same problem:

Find the dll file scriptproxy.dll (usually C:\Program Files\Network
Associates\VirusScan).  Navigate to this path and unregister it with the command:

regsvr32 /u scriptproxy.dll
*** Bug 89223 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I wanted to confirm that Bug 89223 and this seem to be the same even though
the message I was getting wasn't 404, but:

"The document that you have requested is not available. The
link may be wrong, or you may not have the corresponding product feature
installed."

Either uninstalling McAfee or enabling on-access scanning made the help
system work. Doing "regsvr32 /u scriptproxy.dll", however did not, although
I was running VirusScan Enterprise 8.0i/8.0.0 patch level "none". (I went
to the McAfee website, but couldn't find patch 10, or any patches for that
matter.

Thanks for the work around.

I don't believe I was getting the 404 error either.  This sounds the same to me.

Unregistering the .dll was to fix *another* problem with McAfee created by
installing patch level 10 (to fix the Help issue), which proceeded to then screw
up our network shares.  Overall their software is extremely buggy and unstable.

You have to get a support ticket to download patches (which is also very stupid).

I verified that

* With Eclipse 3.0.2 / JRE 1.5.0_02 / VirusScan 8.0.0 patch 1,7 
  the problem is still there, when the TEMP directory is configured
  to be excluded from on-access-scan. As a workaround, make sure to
  allow TEMP to be scanned.

* VirusScan 8.0.0 patch 10 resolves the problem, it is now possible
  to exclude TEMP from scanning.
patch 10 seems to fix it.  I will resolve the bug.
*** Bug 100731 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
